PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire to pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so that sufficient space to answer the questions, don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1920, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family answered the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or copy for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Board No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life What It Was Like" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (—).

Saskatchewan Archives Board No. 2, entitled "Pioneer Life What It Was Like" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please mark this one and one will be sent to you.

Please answer all questions. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Office of the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's archives.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your own experience but may prove impossible or irrelevant to others. It is therefore suggested that you answer the questions most relevant to your own experience. Also, if there are any questions which you feel should be included in the questionnaire, please let us know.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1920. If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life," was distributed to Western Canadian pioneers in 1947 and will be circulated again. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark beside it and we will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:

- Pioneer social life
- Pioneer religious life
- Pioneer sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

Office of the University of Saskatchewan Archives Board's Provincial Archives. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

I'm not sure how much time we have available today. If there's a few minutes left, I'd like to discuss something important with you.

As you know, we've been working on this project for quite some time now. It's been challenging at times, but I believe we're making progress.

One thing I want to mention is the upcoming presentation. We need to ensure that everything is in order by next week. I'll be sending out an email with more details soon.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to hearing your thoughts on this.

Best regards,

[Signature]
A few days later Walter came with a message. He said we must wait until May. We were in our own house and could not go out. My mother said we needed to move away from the town. She said she would take us somewhere else.

We moved into a new house. We were happy there. We went to school and played with other children. We had a good time.

We missed our old home. We missed our friends. We missed our family. We missed our pets.

We were happy in our new home. We were happy to be together again. We were happy to be free.

We were happy to be together again. We were happy to be free.
